alternatives.transcript: welcome to this Thursday edition of take to we're glad you could join us today I'm Don farmer

Great American smokeout is a public relations experts dream this anti-smoking bonfire and Carrollton Georgia fueled by cigarettes was just one of scores of demonstrations and events put on by the anti-smoking groups in the face of all this these bonfires and anti smoking hot lines and such the tobacco Institute remains unflustered pushing ahead with its tobacco industry view that smoking is and should be a matter of free choice even the latest surgeon general's report out earlier today is dismissed by the tobacco Institute is

nothing new so we want to give the tobacco Institute share of the air today to tell us the tobacco industry view of the smoking controversy and to do that we're happy to have with us on take to today the vice president of the tobacco Institute Walker merriment thank you for joining us is mr. Merlyn thank you as you heard and as you knew before it came out the Surgeon General has said it again that smoking is going to kill 170,000 of us this year what do you think about

well I think that as the report noted somewhat grudgingly itself and perhaps it's a part of the report that we could agree with that the precise biologic mechanisms of the relationship to smoking to coronary heart disease remain unknown and I think that they've spent a great deal of time and money and effort presenting this report but that's really about the only thing they say if the if there isn't right now scientific proof

oof exactly how it how it happens if it does in fact happen what do you think of the the linkage the statistics of those who smoke and then the incidence of heart disease what do you make of those well those are gone over very well within the report itself and I'd have to point out that I think anyone who thoroughly reviews the report this year from the Surgeon General will find that the scientific findings which do not support the

editor's preconceived judgments about smoking and coronary heart disease are either ignored or downplayed or admit are omitted and I think prime example of that is the handling of the 115 million dollar seven-year-long multiple risk factor intervention trial and other similar intervention trials which are handled and reviewed in that report mr. Merriman I know a lot of people to smoke I used to smoke

smoke and even those who smoke and have no intention of giving it up when asked will say yeah I'm sure it's not good for me would you say that someone asked asked you that I wouldn't be surprised if that's the majority opinion of smokers and non-smokers I think public opinion polls have shown that for many years is because of all the anti-smoking information that has come out from the surgeon general's office and other agencies voluntary health association's and so forth as

myself as an individual I don't know if smoking is hazardous or not I do happen to be a smoker's I think you know it's not a job requirement at the tobacco Institute where an equal opportunity employer but I think it remains a matter of mature informed individual judgment as Chris said at the beginning why would the government slant the facts in this case do you think that there is that the government is taking facts and using them incorrectly or somehow taking us

special campaign here that you think is an accurate well I would simply urge those who have the opportunity and the inclination to carefully review the report on smoking and heart disease this year to inquire perhaps of some of its acknowledged contributors about the extent to which their original manuscripts survived the editing process at the office of smoking and health there's reason to believe that there was substantial effort on this

I think that we are going to have something more to say on that in particular at a later time why would the government if and I realize you haven't proven it but it's perhaps something you working on why would the government slant the information again smoking in your view I don't know that they have but I would simply say that anyone who looks at this report in-depth should look very carefully at what is said what is reviewed and perhaps speak with some of the

the original acknowledged contributors about their own contributions to the report as you know proposition P strong anti-smoking regulation in the workplace in the office has just been passed in San Francisco what do you think of that kind of legislation well I think proposition P itself was really nothing more than an anomaly as you may know there were seven other occasions the three of them in California for outside the state of California where the voters were

the ballot on something quite similar and they said in all those other seven cases we don't want government coming in here telling us how to arrange our employer or employee relationships or we can set up smoking and non-smoking sections ourselves if we think that's what the people who patronize our business want I don't know what happened in San Francisco but I do know that it's going to be awfully confusing and chaotic there for people who are trying to balance out these relationships and trying to keep people happy in the workplace

mr.
